Problem:
Examine a response system governed by the Laplace transform \(\mathcal{L}(x(t)) = X(s)\) of a function \(x(t)\). Assume an exponential function \(f(x) = e^{kx}\) acts on \(x(t)\) and modifies its behaviour in the Laplace domain.

Does applying the transformation \(f(x) = e^{kx}\) to \(x(t)\) before taking the Laplace transform alter the transformed function \(X(s)\) such that \(s\) is replaced with \(s-k\)?
Explanation: Applying \(\mathcal{L}(e^{kx}x(t))\) results in a modified Laplace transform where every instance of \(s\) is substituted with \(s-k\). This represents the frequency domain scaling effect due to exponential time-domain multiplication.
